scrolly1.text:
Meet your typical tween.
Like many girls her age, she loves to keep up with the latest fashion trends and explore new ways to express herself.

“Junior” clothing sections often channel this interest with styles that feel more adult, but are made to reflect the body proportions of tweens and teens who are still growing and maturing.
The median 10- or 11-year-old wears around a size Medium in Juniors clothing ranges.

scrolly1.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
scrolly1.text:
But not all tweens wear the same size.
Here’s a look at the varying sizes for all 10- and 11-year-old girls from across the U.S.

scrolly1.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
scrolly1.text:
But by age 15, most girls have gone through growth spurts and puberty, and they’ve reached their adult height. Many have outgrown the junior size section.


They may not have the same curves as an adult, but this marks an important turning point for them in being able to try out women’s clothing lines

scrolly1.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
scrolly1.text: Some may find that adult Women’s sizes actually fit better

scrolly1.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
scrolly1.text:
This will be the first time that nearly every girl in their cohort will be able to find sizes in adult clothing ranges that line up within an inch of their waistline measurements.


This will also likely be the last time this ever happens in their lifetimes.


Most adult women do not maintain the physique of a 15-year-old girl — nor probably should they. As they age and reach major life milestones in adulthood — perhaps graduation, marriage, having kids, or advancing in their career — their bodies continue to develop and change. 


But for most women as they progress through life, the range of accessible clothing options will become smaller and smaller. Many, if not most, will have no available sizing options at all.

scrolly1.sizeBands: XXS, XS, S, M, L, XL, XXL
scrolly1.text: By their 20s, a size Medium will no longer reflect the median or average woman’s waistline.

Instead, the median 20-something fits a size 14.


This places them in the middle of what’s sometimes referred to as the “mid-size gap” — a murky space that varies from brand to brand in determining where “regular-” or “straight-size” clothing lines end, and separate “plus-size” ranges begin.

Sizing options are even worse when you look at all adult women over the age of 20.


The median woman in the U.S. fits around a size 18 based on their waistline measurement.


This has meaningful implications.

scrollywaistlines.text:
As sizes have changed, so too have our waistlines.

Between 1988 and 1994, the average woman’s waistline was 34.88 inches. By 2018, it was 38.74

scrollyvanity.text: For years, many have blamed sizing inconsistencies on so-called “vanity sizing,” a practice that assumes women are more likely to buy clothes labeled as sizes that are smaller than they actually are. And while vanity sizing has indeed shifted how we label each size, there’s more to the story.

scrollyvanity2.text: This is what standard sizes looked like in 1995…
…And here is how they looked in 2021
Notice how in 1995, a 27-inch waist was considered a size 8; in 2021 it was between sizes 2 and 4

scrolly3.text:
With each update, however, the ASTM sizes have continued to skew toward the smallest women, leaving out nearly half of the population

In many ways, this has been intentional.

ASTM has said itself that it’s not trying to develop a system that accurately reflects modern demographics in America.

Instead, the system is just as much tailored to conventional beauty standards and what clothing brands consider to be their ideal customer.

The underlying foundation of the modern sizing system is inherently skewed by age and race as well.

It’s based on a 1941 study that only captured the body measurements of white, mostly young, middle class women from urban areas within just a handful of states.

Since the sizing chart’s inception, measurements have been tailored to young, white bodies while promoting conventional beauty standards like the hourglass silhouette. This matters because we know that age and genetics factor quite a bit into our shape and body proportions. The result has meant that middle aged black and hispanic women have had a particularly difficult time accessing sizes that fit

scrolly4.displayedBrands: COS, Louis Vuitton, Prada, Anthropologie, Uniqlo
scrolly4.text: Many prominent (particularly high-end) brands do not carry sizes higher than a size 14 or 16

scrolly4.displayedBrands: COS, Louis Vuitton, Prada, Anthropologie, Uniqlo, Shein, Aritzia, J.Crew, Old Navy, H&M
scrolly4.text: Some brands carry extended options within their “Regular” or “Straight” size ranges

scrolly4.displayedBrands: COS, Louis Vuitton, Prada, Anthropologie, Uniqlo, Shein, Aritzia, J.Crew, Old Navy, H&M
scrolly4.text: While others have a “Plus” size range that is kept separate, often with simpler styles that differ from other straight size collections
